Medium Analysis Pet Project

ğŸ“ About This Project

I created this project to explore what drives engagement on Medium â€” using public data and hands-on Python analysis.

I analyzed ~1,800 Medium articles to uncover patterns in claps, reading time, and responses. This page walks through the full process, including: â€¢ Cleaning and transforming the data â€¢ Generating summary statistics and visualizations â€¢ Extracting insights useful for content planning

All visuals and analysis are now fully integrated below using Python and Quarto â€” no external dashboards required.

ğŸ§° Tools & Skills

  • Python (Pandas, Matplotlib, Seaborn) for data cleaning and analysis
  • Quarto to publish analysis
  • Data storytelling â€” summarizing patterns into insights
  • Strategic thinking from a content managerâ€™s view

ğŸ“‚ Dataset

  • Source: Kaggle - Medium Articles Dataset
    Contains metadata for ~1,800 Medium articles: title, claps, responses, reading time, publication, date

ğŸ“Š Key Findings

  • The Startup dominates top clapped articles â€” strong brand power
  • Best-performing articles tend to be 6â€“9 minutes
  • Most articles receive <5 responses, with a few outliers
  • Engagement peaks in early Q1, suggesting seasonal behavior

ğŸ¯ Why I Did This

This project simulates a real-world editorial question:

â€œWhat types of stories perform best on Medium, and how can writers use data to plan better content?â€

By combining public data, Python, and lightweight reporting tools, I aimed to show how a modern content strategist might use data.

ğŸ§ª Analysis Summary (Python)

To start the analysis, I loaded the dataset and imported key libraries used for data wrangling and visualization:

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

sns.set(style="whitegrid")

df = pd.read_csv("data/medium_data.csv")

The data includes article metadata such as publication, reading time, claps, and responses. Next, I cleaned and prepared the dataset for analysis.

ğŸ§ª Data Cleaning

Before analyzing the data, I cleaned and prepared it by: - Parsing the publication date - Filtering out articles with zero claps - Calculating a new feature: claps per minute of reading time

df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date'], dayfirst=True)
df = df[df['claps'] > 0].copy()
df['claps_per_min'] = df['claps'] / df['reading_time']

ğŸ§ª Descriptive Stats

df[['claps', 'reading_time', 'responses']].describe()

ğŸ§ª Visualizing Distributions

To understand the general spread and outliers in the dataset, I visualized the distributions of claps, reading time, and responses using boxplots. This helped surface skewed engagement patterns and typical article behavior.

plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))

# Claps
plt.subplot(1, 3, 1)
sns.boxplot(x=df['claps'])
plt.title('Claps')

# Reading Time
plt.subplot(1, 3, 2)
sns.boxplot(x=df['reading_time'])
plt.title('Reading Time')

# Responses
plt.subplot(1, 3, 3)
sns.boxplot(x=df['responses'])
plt.title('Responses')

plt.tight_layout(pad=2)
plt.show()

Boxplots show that:

â€¢   Claps are heavily right-skewed with a few viral outliers
â€¢   Reading time is typically 5â€“10 minutes
â€¢   Responses are sparse, with most articles receiving very few
